newsitem.title: UK: Oil prices dip, but Mexican storm stems the drift.
newsitem.headline: Oil prices dip, but Mexican storm stems the drift.

text.p: World oil prices continued to slide for the second day on Wednesday following the sharp gains posted over the past week.
But storm-related shutdowns of key oil export ports in Mexico kept a floor under prices, traders said.
October futures for world benchmark Brent Blend crude from the North Sea closed at $20.21 a barrel, 26 cents below Tuesday's close but five cents above Wednesday's low.
"The market needs to come down from the lofty gains we saw earlier, but the Mexican storms drew in some buying," a London broker said.
Oil prices hit four-month highs in recent days as nervous buyers looked to top up low heating oil stocks ahead of the winter.

Tropical Storm Dolly forced Mexican state oil company Pemex to shut its three Gulf of Mexico oil ports on Wednesday. Mexico is a major supplier of oil to the United States and one of the world's largest oil producers.
But the shutdown was seen as precautionary and its bullish impact momentary, some traders said.
They said short-term supply-demand fundamentals led them to expect further price erosion.
Underlining the bearish undertone was news that some European refiners were slowing down production to combat weak profit margins.
Relatively high crude oil prices and low refined product prices have cut into refiner earnings in recent days, although there are signs of improvement.
Margins improved sharply on Tuesday after hitting 18-month lows on Friday but the recovery was not enough to stop some refineries in France, Italy, Sweden and Britain from cutting throughput.
When refiners cut runs, their appetite for crude oil falls as they use less of it to make refined products like gasoline and heating oil.
Crude oil prices in dollars per barrel:
